reviewText:
Rainbow Six Vegas was an effective and divisive reboot of the Rainbow Six series. It took the previously slow and tactical shooter series into a much more modern cover shooter direction. I say divisive because Rainbow Six Vegas caused a split in the fanbase between people who wanted a faster cover shooter and people who wanted a slower game where you plan your movements before executing.

Rainbow Six Vegas largely takes place in the titular city of Las Vegas. You play as Logan" an operative for the titular "Rainbow" special forces team who enters the city to combat a terrorist threat. The storytelling is a bit muddled and you generally don't pay attention to it that much. It mostly serves to get you from point A to Point B and shoot some baddies.

What Rainbow Six Vegas is most well known for it's cover shooter gameplay. While it is faster than all of the previous Rainbow Six games it's noticeably slower than say
date: Call of Duty or Gears of War. The game is built around using your squadmates to move to different positions so you can flank or take enemies out from a distance. It's much more forgiving as well since it has regenerating health and the enemy AI is fairly dumb. Since you die very quickly the game doesn't devolve into run and gun but it still feels much slower than it should.\n\nBesides the campaign
recommended: Rainbow Six Vegas also has multiplayer and Terrorist Hunt. The latter is where the game excels in my opinion. In Terrorist Hunt
hoursPlayed: you and a few friends can team up to take out AI enemies in a series of multiplayer maps. It's very enjoyable and replayable and is where the bulk of the time you spend playing the game will end up. Deathmatch is also available but good luck finding a game for it.\n\nIt's hard to really describe the original Rainbow Six Vegas without describing how much better it's sequel was. While I do recommend the game if you're a fan of modern shooters and desire something that requires slightly more thought behind it

reviewText:
The game is based on hunting terrorists in Las Vegas and true to other Rainbow games, a single head shot can kill you or your enemies. There is no tactical planning or waypoint setting, but a map can be overlaid in real time to show enemy/friendly positions and objectives.
During the game different approaches to reach objectives can be made which may involve fast roping, abseiling or ladder use to traverse drops and climbs. Your team of two non-player characters can be sent to any location within view (but not separately) and are reasonably reactive to incoming fire taking cover and returning fire when required. The range of weapons and customisation is vast and picking the correct weapons for the scenario is vital for success. My favourite action is being able to sneak view under doors and tag enemies for the NPC's to attack before door entry is made. Onto the health system, there is no health bar in this game. Instead when you are shot your vision becomes blurry. This means you have to take cover and rest until the blurriness has gone. It may not be a realistic health system but it adds to the intenseness of firefights and works very well.
There are a ton of weapons to play around with. Sub machine guns, light machine guns, sniper rifles, shotguns, pistols, shield. All of these are tweak able with different scopes, magazines, laser sights etc.

Flying around, destination to destination and rappelling down from a helicopter to engage a great threat, be it terrorists in Mexico, Vegas or the Hoover dam, this is one of the best (if not the best) co-op tactical shooter experiences you will get.

Seriously one of the best R6 games out there. The graphics are great (once you adjust brightness to around 4-5, which makes the contrast much nicer and the game look less bland) and it seriously beats out its sequel, Vegas 2. Interesting level designs, believable and awesome attention to detail- from the wrecked slums of a Mexican ghetto, to the wealth driven Vegas strip with poker chips flying out of slot machines, it's truly a wonderful achievement for a 2006 game. The shooting is wonderful, with a great cover system that, while not entirely realistic, is great for a tactical title. The AI shout commands at eachother, exclaim words of disbelief as their comrades perish, and your allies are not brick stupid like in Vegas 2. It is not without flaws, though. The AI will ocassionally spazz out, this is easily fixed by ordering them to move somewhere, and the game has not been updated since 07, its highest resolution setting makes the Xbox One giggle- this is easily fixed with an auto-patcher (http://community.pcgamingwiki.com/files/file/103-tom-clancys-rainbow-six-vegas-resolution-patcher/) and brings the game up to date. The game lacks a lot of graphics options, which were supposedly included via a launcher the CD version came with.

The story is wonderful, very compelling and intriguing- very Tom Clancy-ish. You can tell they actually cared when making this game, as opposed to its rushed out, still-the-same-graphics and models, sequel.
If you want my honest truth, this game is everything Vegas 2 should have been. The customization is the same, the music is better, the audio is better, the settings are much better and the characters are not utterly stupid. The ending to this game is far more rewarding than the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they threw in with the sequel, not to mention the plot twists actually make sense and will make you go oh" as opposed to make you giggle like a rampant meth addict like it will in the sequel.

reviewText:
A casual and accessible tactical shooter that is a joy to play, even if it is no Ghost Recon
Compared to more hardcore Tom Clancy games like Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter, RB6V can feel like a simplified generic shooter. That may indeed be the case, but it's fun and quite replayable, especially in co-op mode.

The gameplay is reminiscent of Gears of War, except you're in first-person mode when not in cover, and you can issue basic tactical orders to your teammates. You'll probably never actually do any fighting from first-person mode, however, because your ability to take damage is very limited even on Normal difficulty, making it almost impossible to win a gunfight without using cover (which puts you into third person view, and lets you blind-fire if you want which is pretty cool).

A few of the basic tactical options like the ability to change the weapon rate-of-fire and attach suppressors are present, which is much welcome. You usually have a choice between going all Rambo into the next area, or playing it safe by going in stealthily and taking everyone by surprise with a few well-placed stun grenades. You also get to feel like a badass in some sequences, rappelling down the side of a building then crashing through the window and saving the hostages.

The game can be hard at times, but in a way that feels justified and encourages you to rethink your strategy instead of yelling at the screen. It can get frustrating when you fail a mission because an AI teammate went down, but that's not too common because the AI is quite smart and is often capable of clearing a room without your help.

Co-op is where this game really shines. It's essential to coordinate the attack plan before opening the next door, and that makes for particularly satisfying breach moments, as you mercilessly pick off those terrorist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and then yell Clear!".

reviewText:
Mix together a bizarre regenerating health system that seems to randomly choose whether you die in one hit or not, which defeats the purpose of regenerating health, and cover-based shooting in flashy, claustrophobic Casino environments and you have Rainbow Six Vegas.

I beat this on the 360 when it originally came out and had a fun time with it, though I don't remember it being anywhere near this frustratingly bull-♥♥♥♥.  Enemies will no-scope you from cover from 200 feet away with a shotgun and insta-kill you *SOMETIMES* or maybe do barely any damage to you.  This inconsistency makes the game feel like bipolar mess which can either make you feel like breezing through it, or smashing your keyboard in rage because of being one-shotted by some ♥♥♥-hat hiding behind something you should clearly be able to shoot through, only to reload the checkpoints.  And yet, I still found myself wanting to push onward and beat the annoying ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

It combines a beyond simplified interface compared to previous Rainbow Six games with no pre-planning, but offers reasonable weapon customization.  You can freely add a silencer to almost any assault rifle or pistol, and it gives you the option of using the shield which I found worked and sometimes it didn't.  The AI is reasonably smart, and will try and flash bang you, use lethal grenades when you're using the shield a lot, and I found that they can lose track of you during a fire-fight.  Silencers appear useless at first because of the linearity of the game, but I found it helps keep the AI guessing where you are, so that they won't always be able to find where the fire is coming from during combat, or right before, so it's less about finishing objectives undetected and more about utilizing stealth as a way to ambush.

The objectives are quite visually appealing with lots of interesting design choices in the environment, and enemies don't just instantly ragdoll when you kill them, as you'll see a mix of ragdoll with the physics of where you shot them plus an animation based on where you shot them, which makes kills very satisfying.  Overall, Rainbow Six is no longer the tactical shooter it was.  It is now a Cover-shooter, with tactical elements.  I suppose the change was evident from Raven Shield to Lockdown, but it seems they've done what Lockdown couldn't, which was making the game interesting for the player.

P.S. For some reason, Vegas 1 looks better than Vegas 2, and plays better than Vegas 2 as well.

reviewText:
I've been a fan of the Rainbow Six series since the beginning but after Raven Shield the series headed in a console centric direction. While Vegas has the console feel but still it a great game on the PC.

The play commands Logan Keller the new team leader of Rainbow, a international anti-terrorist organization, sent to a Mexican border town to capture Irena Morales who is a terrorist ringleader. Failing to capture Irena, Keller is ordered to head to Las Vegas to handle a new crisis there. The story is on par with any Tom Clancy book or game so it filled with action and a couple plot twists but overall its not memorable.

Gameplay takes on new features from previous installments. One is the cover system much like Kill.switch and Gears Of War players can take cover against almost anything and either blind fire to give covering fire or pop up and shoot. Another add in is a regenerative health system that is much like any other game that has one. In previous Rainbow Six games before each mission but with the going more console centric that went away and was replaced a simple order giving control scheme which in Vegas was refined and is pretty simple to give your team members orders to breach, grenade, flash, clear, etc.

Sound FX do sound great in the case of the weapon fire and other general FX's and the voice work is good and fit the game well and while the soundtrack is good and fits the game its just the same orchestral work like most games.

Overall the game is a great game to experience for fans of the Rainbow Six series.

7/10

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Vegas is if anything a mediocre FPS that while entertaining at times, doesn't bring anything new to the table. Really, the game is just simply put, average.

The plot is a straight out of a generic action-thriller movie that involves a WMD in the middle of the Vegas Strip, and only you and your squad can save Sin City and all its morally-questionable fun. This plain jane story is presented through some of the cheesiest voice-acting I've ever heard; foul-mouthed terrorists and an overly 'Murican protagonist are the first things your auditory senses will register. Your squadmates are no better either, although Jun has to be the less obnoxious of the two since he has the decency to not spout off 80's era catchphrases and one-liners every 15 seconds.

Gameplay is as I've mentioned before, mediocre and not notable in a market that's got more shooters than rounds fired in the average round of Battlefield. The only real variety that Vegas has to seperate itself is a cover mechanic and a few contextual commands for your squad (such as breaching a door). While this may be a step above something like Call of Duty, compared to older Rainbow six games, such as the legendary Rainbow six 3, the oversimplified mechanic is a major letdown. Regardless, the cover mechanic is helpful in combating the hordes of profanity spewing bad guys who seems to have more ammunition than braincells. Once again, your squadmates aren't all that smarter, but they do make a handy distraction when the brown hits the fan and can do a decent amount of damage if you set them up in a good spot where they can rain down lead.

reviewText:
Rainbow Six Vegas offers a decent tactical shooter experience by allowing the player multiple ways of dealing with situations in the game (choosing an enterance, method of entry etc.) and allowing the player to regularly select their loadouts of different weapons and equipment.

This particular Rainbow Six title falls short on many things however; with poor story character voice acting, clunky controls, incompetent friendly AI, enemy AI with stupidly inhuman reflexes, and an awful damage system which blinds the player when hit and forces him to sit and do nothing for a good few seconds, killing the flow.

I personally found this game unjustifiably frustrating a bit too often but after completing the campaign I felt a satisfying sense of accomplishment, a consistent characteristic in the Rainbow Six series. It's a decent shooter and it's something to try if you're looking for a game that doesn't hold your hand.

Its definitly a must have shooter, not only for fans of R6 (since they have very little in common), but for players that like FPS very action oriented and with some tactic mixed up, and now you can get it for reasonable price wich make your purchase worth while.

This game is fun as a single player tactical shooter, with the ability to order your AI teammates to advance, breach/clear rooms etc.

However :
- the hostiles are sometimes impossible to see. I found myself literally pixel hunting in some of the levels to try to distinguish the enemy AI from the background. It doesn't help that the hostiles can shoot you through surfaces that are transparent to them but opaque to you (including foliage and lattices)
- hostiles spawn regardless of your approach; stealth is not rewarded. Blitzkreig through an area and find 5 hostiles round the corner expecting you, reload the area and sneakily kill everyone without alerting anyone, you will still find those 5 hostiles expecting you
- checkpoints are few and far between. Ostensibly clear an area, complete the objectives, get 1-hit by a hostile standing across the map behind a hedge, tough **** you're gonna have to do it all again.

All these factors make it a frustrating experience to play.

reviewText: This is one of the first shooter games I played and it's got a load of memories. The graphics aren't bad, some could say they're fantastic for the release. I enjoy ragdolls in action games and this delivers. I used to run a slow computer and this game literally ran as smooth as anything. It doesn't require a buffed computer which is nice. The weapons aren't too varied, but there's still a decent selection [don't worry though, they've got every type of weapons excluding RPGs]. On top of that, the physics are pretty nice and if you're not satisfied you can set them to realistic [you die way quicker and AIs are more difficult]. You won't see someone die from one shot unless the weapon is buffed or you get a headshot. That's also nice, unlike other games, you actually kill them one shot if it's critical. A warning to any choir-boys out there though, this game has some intense language. You'll hear racial slurs, vulgar language, and words you've probably never heard before. As for the story, it's pretty well written with nice maps. If you ever get bored you've got the classic terrorist hunts which are a good practice lol.
